message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Read Before You Cite!
Paper Abstract: We report a method for estimating what percentage of people who cited a paper had actually read it. The method is based on a stochastic modeling of the citation process that explains empirical studies of misprint distributions in citations (which we show follows a Zipf law). Our estimate is that only about 20% of citers read the original.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here's what I found about Zipf's Law:

## Definition

Zipf's law is an empirical law stating that when a set of measured values is sorted in decreasing order, the value of the n-th entry is often approximately inversely proportional to n.

## Word Frequency Application

The most common word occurs approximately twice as often as the next common one, three times as often as the third most common, and so on. For example, in the Brown Corpus of American English text, the word "the" accounts for nearly 7% of all word occurrences, while "of" accounts for slightly over 3.5%.

## Origin and History

This law is named after the American linguist George Kingsley Zipf. Though the pattern was first observed by German physicist Felix Auerbach in 1913, and later discovered independently by French stenographer Jean-Baptiste Estoup in 1916.

## Broader Applications

The law has been found to apply to many other types of data studied in the physical and social sciences.(no content)When corporations are ranked by decreasing size, their sizes are found to be inversely proportional to the rank, and the same relation is found for personal incomes, number of people watching the same TV channel, and other variables.

## Mathematical Formalization

In mathematical statistics, the concept has been formalized as the Zipfian distribution: A family of related discrete probability distributions whose rank-frequency distribution is an inverse power law relation.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of citation publishing:

## What is Citation Publishing?

A bibliographic citation is a reference to a book, article, web page, or other published item.(no content)Citations should supply sufficient detail to identify the item uniquely.

## Citation Systems and Styles

Different citation systems and styles are used in scientific citation, legal citation, prior art, the arts, and the humanities. Some common styles include:

- MLA style was developed by the Modern Language Association and is most often used in the arts and the humanities, particularly in English studies
- The American Chemical Society style, or ACS style, is often used in chemistry and some of the physical sciences.

## Purpose and Structure

Wikipedia's verifiability policy requires inline citations for any material challenged or likely to be challenged, and for all quotations. Each section of text that is either based on, or quoted from, an outside source is marked as such with an inline citation, usually displayed as a superscript footnote number. The second necessary part of the citation or reference is the list of full references, which provides complete, formatted detail about the source.

## Data Publishing

An emerging area in citation publishing is data publication. Publishing data allows researchers to both make their data available to others to use, and enables datasets to be cited similarly to other research publication types (such as articles or books), thereby enabling producers of datasets to gain academic credit for their work.

Links: [{"title":"Stochastic modelling (insurance) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_modelling_(insurance)"},{"title":"Stochastic process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_process"},{"title":"Stochastic simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_simulation"},{"title":"Stochastic dynamic programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_dynamic_programming"},{"title":"Dynamic stochastic general equilibrium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_stochastic_general_equilibrium"},{"title":"Stochastic programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_programming"},{"title":"Stochastic optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_optimization"},{"title":"Stochastic geometry models of wireless networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_geometry_models_of_wireless_networks"},{"title":"Markov model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_model"},{"title":"Gaussian process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gaussian_process"}]

Based on the web search results, here's a comprehensive overview of stochastic modeling:

## Definition

Stochastic processes are widely used as mathematical models of systems and phenomena that appear to vary in a random manner.

## Core Concept

Rather than setting parameters according to their most likely estimate, stochastic models use random variations, and based on a set of random variables, the experience of a system is projected, and the outcome is noted.(no content)Stochastic modelling builds volatility and variability (randomness) into the simulation and therefore provides a better representation of real life from more angles.

## Key Characteristics

At the end, a distribution of outcomes is available which shows not only the most likely estimate but what ranges are reasonable too.(no content)Stochastic models help to assess the interactions between variables, and are useful tools to numerically evaluate quantities, as they are usually implemented using Monte Carlo simulation techniques.

## Applications

Stochastic modeling is used across various fields, including:
- **Insurance**: Useful when a policy or fund provides a guarantee, e.g. a minimum investment return of 5% per annum.
- **Economics**: Dynamic stochastic general equilibrium modeling is a macroeconomic method which is often employed by monetary and fiscal authorities for policy analysis, explaining historical time-series data, as well as future forecasting purposes.
- **Optimization**: Stochastic programming is a framework for modeling optimization problems that involve uncertainty.
- **Wireless networks**: Stochastic geometry models of wireless networks are mathematical models designed to represent aspects of wireless networks, with research analyzing these models to better understand and predict various network performance metrics.

purpose: Extract transferable techniques and methodologies from research papers

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [in_progress] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [pending] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [pending] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

| Entity | Type | Relation | Wikipedia URL | Relevance |
